metadata.title: Interesting AI/ML Articles On Medium This Week (Nov 28) | by Richmond Alake | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Interesting AI/ML Articles On Medium This Week (Nov 28)
metadata.description: As the week comes to a close, I typically round up a list of well written and interesting articles that relates to Artificial Intelligence or Machine Learning. Medium is excellent at recommending…

all_paragraphs: As the week comes to a close, I typically round up a list of well written and interesting articles that relates to Artificial Intelligence or Machine Learning.
Medium is excellent at recommending articles that show high levels of interaction. Articles that have loads of engagements will make it to your home feed and email inboxes.
But at times, there are hidden gems that do not get the attention they deserve.
This is where I come in.
All articles recommended within this article have teachings and information that will benefit machine learning practitioners of all sorts.
Check out the “Target Audience” information to check if an article fits your ML profile.
Target Audience: Futurists, Individuals with Interests in AI-generated Content

Christopher Brennan explores a future where the difference between texts that are AI-generated and ones that are written by human might be only distinguishable through a label that says ‘AI-generated’.
This article depicts a future where AI-generated content is prominent. With an abundance of information on your likes and interests, these generated content are engineered just for you.

Although several figureheads within the Deep Learning fields have downplayed the applicability of large language models like GPT3, Christopher suggests in this article that it might not take much ‘intelligence’ to blur the lines between human and AI-generated content on the internet.
David Yakobovitch article is included in this recommended list for the sole reason that it acts as a blueprint for parents to introduce their children to the world of AI.
In this article, David makes several cases on the advantages and the necessity of informing children as to how AI works.
Parents would be sure to check this article out, as it contains useful resources on applications that teach kids AI, including methods and strategies on getting children initially interested in AI.
Target Audience: General Audience (No technical knowledge required)
Naf explores the yet, or rather soon to be, implications of AI-generated faces within the human society.

This article is a pleasant read with well put together sentences and statements that navigates the worlds of AI, hypothetical future, movies, and ethics, when discussing the issues that could arise from AI-generated faces and more broadly content.
Target Audience: Machine Learning Engineers (Mobile focused)
This article is a transcription of a podcast, for readers who prefer to listen as opposed to read, click here to view the video version.
This article details the conversation held between Jeremie Harris and Matthew Stewart on subject matters concerning machine learning models on edge devices (smartphones, microcontroller etc.).

Matthew provides a wealth of information and insights into the world of TinyML. Matthew provides a description of TinyML, including use cases and limitations on processes involved in converting large ML models to small models that are mere kilobytes in size, but still function as expected.

Upon reading this article, readers should be prepared to get information on how to prepare for a future where ML models are embedded within typical household appliances, and the individuals, frameworks, libraries that are currently making this possible.
Target Audience: Individuals transitioning into Data Science.
Renato article is a short exploratory piece on the efficacy of Data Science bootcamps during Covid era.
Data Science bootcamps and bootcamps, in general, are a path many consider when transitioning into data science or tech roles without the relevant prior background or skills required.
Renato mentions in this article the key benefit of bootcamps, which is the human interaction attendees have with other bootcamps attendees, instructors and potential employers.
The key benefits of bootcamps are lost as a result of covid related self-isolation, social distancing and lockdowns.
In this article, Renato explains if bootcamps are still worth paying a premium price.
There’s even a suggestion of a hybrid Bootcamp that might interest some readers.
And if you are a machine learning practitioner, you probably would entertain the thought of a pizza-making robot.
Travis writes on the topics of AI Safety, AI Accident and cleverly illustrates scenarios using a pizza-making robot.
This article is an intuitive explanation of the importance of AI safety and methods by which AI accidents can occur.
Each method of accident occurrence is supplemented with statements on possible solutions.
Travis also emphasises that it’s our responsibilities as machine learning practitioners to ensure that the models and systems we put out to the world are safe for use.
To connect with me or find more content similar to this article, do the following:
Your home for data science. A Medium publication sharing concepts, ideas and codes.
Machine Learning Content Creator with 1M+ views— Computer Vision Engineer. Interested in gaining and sharing knowledge on Technology and Finance
